Key Arguments: The legislation is seen as a threat to freedom of speech and expression, likened to Orwellian censorship.
There is a belief that the legislation would enforce a government narrative and suppress alternative viewpoints.
Concerns about the ACMA's ability to make objective decisions and the potential for politically motivated guidelines.
The proposed powers for ACMA are viewed as excessive and could lead to government overreach.
The penalties associated with the legislation are considered unfair and could lead to self-censorship.
The legislation is perceived as a move towards totalitarianism and a threat to democratic principles.
Notable Quotes: This legislation would take away from the individual citizen's right to receive information and decide the worth of it for themselves.
This is the worst type of Orwellian censorship and worthy only of a fascist state.
The draft Bill inhibits freedom of expression and forces us to adopt the mainstream narrative even when we strongly oppose it.
If this legislation is accepted the Government would solely control what is mis or disinformation and remove the rights of Australians to free speech.
